title: Lalita Sahasranama
author: Sage Hayagrīva (narrated in Brahmanda Purana)
introduction:
The Lalita Sahasranama is one of the most sacred texts in Shaktism, dedicated to the Hindu Mother Goddess Lalita Tripurasundari, the form of the Divine Mother (Shakti) who governs the three worlds. This hymn appears in the Uttara Khanda of the Brahmanda Purana and is presented as a conversation between the sage Agastya and Lord Hayagrīva (an incarnation of Vishnu).

Unlike other Sahasranamas (thousand names) which may contain repetitive or manufactured names, the Lalita Sahasranama is unique because it is said to have been composed by the Goddess herself at the request of the Vāgdevatas (Goddesses of Speech), ensuring its flawless and supreme nature.

Recitation of the Sahasranama is central to the worship of Lalita and is believed to grant spiritual merit, prosperity, and liberation (moksha). The names systematically describe the Goddess's physical attributes, her divine weapons (like the sugarcane bow and flowery arrows), her glorious pastimes, and her role as the ultimate creator, maintainer, and destroyer of the universe.

chapters.name: Stotra (The Hymn of 1000 Names)
chapters.summary: The main devotional hymn containing the 1,000 epithets of Lalita Tripurasundari, as narrated by Hayagrīva. The names detail her divine form, actions, abode, and cosmic powers, forming the central core of her worship (Arcana). This section is traditionally followed by the Phalaśruti (results of recitation).

verses.original:
सिन्दूरारुणविग्रहां त्रिनयनां माणिक्यमौलि स्फुरत्
तारानायक शेखरां स्मितमुखी मापीन वक्षोरुहाम्।
पाणिभ्यामलिपूर्ण रत्न चषकं रक्तोत्पलं बिभ्रतीं
सौम्यां रत्न घटस्थ रक्त चरणां ध्यायेत् पराम्बिकाम्॥
verses.transliteration:
sindūrāruṇavigrahāṁ trinayanāṁ māṇikyamouli sphurat
tārānāyaka śekharāṁ smitamukhī māpīna vakṣōruhām.
pāṇibhyāmalipūrṇa ratna caṣakaṁ raktōtpalaṁ bibhratīṁ
saumyāṁ ratna ghaṭastha rakta caraṇāṁ dhyāyēt parāmbikām.

translations.english: We meditate upon the Supreme Mother, whose form is red like vermilion, who has three eyes, whose crown is adorned with glittering rubies and the moon (leader of stars), who has a smiling face and full breasts, who holds a jewel-filled cup of wine and a red lotus in her hands, who is gentle, and whose red feet are placed upon a jeweled pot.

The Holy Mother (Śrīmātā), the Great Empress (Śrīmahārājñī), the Sovereign of the Auspicious Throne (Śrīmatsimhāsaneśvarī), who emerged from the fire pit of consciousness (Cidagnikuṇḍasambhūtā), and who is zealous in accomplishing the work of the Gods (Devakāryasamudyatā). (Names 1-4)

She shines with the radiance of a thousand rising suns (Udyadbhānusahasrābhā), endowed with four arms (Caturbāhusamantvitā), holds the noose which is the form of attachment (Rāgasvarūpapāśāḍhyā), and shines with the goad which is the form of anger (Krōdhākārāṅkuśōjjvalā). (Names 5-8)

Her sugarcane bow is the form of the mind (Manōrūpēkṣukōdaṇḍā), her five arrows are the five subtle elements (Pañcatanmātrasāyakā), and the entire universe is immersed in the flood of her innate reddish radiance (Nijāruṇaprabhāpūramajjadbrahmāṇḍamaṇḍalā). (Names 9-11)

Her charming locks of hair carry the sweet fragrance of Campaka, Aśoka, and Punnāga flowers (Campakāśōkapunnāgasaugandhikalatskacā), and she is decorated with a crown sparkling with rows of Kuruvinda gems (Kuruvindamaṇiśrēṇīkanatkōṭīra maṇḍitā). (Names 12-14)

Her forehead is adorned with the luster of the crescent moon of the eighth lunar day (Aṣṭamīcandra vibhrājadalasthalavirājitā), and the mark (tilaka) of musk on her forehead resembles the spot on the moon (Mukhacandrakalaṅkābhamṛganābhiviśēṣakā). (Names 15-18)

Her two rows of teeth shine like the sprout of Śuddha Vidya (Śuddhavidyaṅkurākāradvijapaṅktidvayōjjvalā), and the scent of the betel leaf (Karpūra Vīṭikā) she chews fills all the directions (Karpūravīṭikāsāmōdapūrita diṅñukhā). (Names 19-21)
